“To CORRECT risks at the system/application layer” – if the actual question mentions web traffic then C is answer, else D is answer. 
not (A) IDS/IPS detects not corrects – not (B) IP tunneling (also known as “port forwarding”) uses PPTE and GRE occurring at the Transport layer – not (C) A WAF is for web traffic - question doesn’t mention web traffic specifically.- leaves (D) patch management (corrects risks for systems and applications).

I think the answer is D, based on CompTIA definition:

Corrective—the control acts to eliminate or reduce the impact of an intrusion event. A corrective control is used after an attack. A good example is a backup system that can restore data that was damaged during an intrusion. Another example is a patch management system that acts to eliminate the vulnerability exploited during the attack.
___
So, for me, the keywords are system/application (we have patch management for systems and applications) and patch management is a corrective measure. Other solutions, which can bring confusion, WAF and IPS, are not intended to correct the situation after an attack, but to prevent the attack
